qas.question: What was the price for early HDTVs?
Did MUSE have a large or small target market, even in Japan?
What were some movies that were released on MUSE LaserDiscs?

answers.text: Terminator 2: Judgment Day, Lawrence of Arabia, A League of Their Own, Bugsy, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Bram Stoker's Dracula and Chaplin

context: In order to view MUSE encoded discs, it was necessary to have a MUSE decoder in addition to a compatible player. There are televisions with MUSE decoding built-in and set top tuners with decoders that can provide the proper MUSE input. Equipment prices were high, especially for early HDTVs which generally eclipsed <a0_0>US$10,000<a0_0/>, and even in Japan the market for MUSE was <a1_0>tiny<a1_0/>. Players and discs were never officially sold in North America, although several distributors imported MUSE discs along with other import titles. <a2_0>Terminator 2: Judgment Day, Lawrence of Arabia, A League of Their Own, Bugsy, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Bram Stoker's Dracula and Chaplin<a2_0/> were among the theatrical releases available on MUSE LDs. Several documentaries, including one about Formula One at Japan's Suzuka Circuit were also released.
